newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: NZ dollar slides at close as dollar-yen zooms up.
newsitem.headline: NZ dollar slides at close as dollar-yen zooms up.

text.p: The New Zealand dollar, caught in the backwash of a rampant U.S. move against the yen, closed sharply weaker on Thursday.
However, the greenback's jump boosted the Trade-Weighted Index to 67.62 from its 67.26 opening.

The dollar ended nearly 3-1/2 yen higher after Japanese Finance Ministry official Eisuke Sakakibara commented that Japan's trade surplus was not a major issue at the upcoming G7 summit and an imminent rate rise was unlikely.
The kiwi closed at 5.00 p.m. at US$0.6880/85, where it is said to have solid support, against its 0.6916/23 opening.
Its behaviour was mild compared with most currencies although many players took the opportunity to sell into the rising TWI.
Against the Australian dollar, the kiwi strengthened 20 basis points to A$0.9147/59 which took a half-cent tumble to 16-month lows on much weaker than expected employment data.
The aussie's fall dragged the kiwi with it and some traders used the kiwi's relative strength to buy aussie.
However, the kiwi is seen gaining further on the aussie with today's jobs data increasing the likelihood of another rate cut.
Dealers said the 10 basis point fall in New Zealand short rates would further dampen demand for new eurokiwi issues.
"Maybe they are not as attractive as they were even this morning or yesterday," said an Auckland-based dealer.
"A lot of the demand that has kept the kiwi at these really high levels has been euro-related. If euro demand was to subside, or disappear completely, you have to wonder where the buyers come from."
